patterns.pattern: First-time contributors (0 prior PRs) with no merge history have baseline ~24% merge rate; XS/S size labels boost this to ~26-28%, while L/M sizes remain at baseline
Experienced-contributor or trusted-contributor labels provide +5-15% boost to merge probability regardless of recent merge rate, offsetting poor historical performance
Maintainer label presence correlates with ~90%+ merge rates and overrides negative author history signals
Authors with 40%+ merge rates (2+ prior successful merges) are strong merge candidates even with limited PR volume or missing metadata
Bug fixes and security fixes merge at higher rates than feature additions, particularly from unknown authors
Narrow, focused scope (single component/category) improves merge odds for new contributors by ~15-20% compared to multi-channel/multi-component changes
Touching multiple channels simultaneously is a risk signal for new/low-history authors, reducing merge probability by ~25-30%
Missing LoC/test/CI data weakens predictions but does not override positive author history or maintainer labels
High-volume component areas (agents: 1161 PRs, commands: 427 PRs) may increase triage pressure, slightly reducing merge rates for new contributors by ~5-10%
Top-contributor status (50+ prior PRs) can sustain merge probability despite recent 0% merge rate if paired with focused scope and fix-type changes
Test-focused PRs from low-merge-history authors have moderate boost (~10-15% above baseline) due to structural value
Chore/docs/infrastructure category changes from unknown authors merge at rates comparable to baseline (~24-25%), independent of scope breadth
Authors with 0% historical merge rate but 5+ prior PRs show commitment signal; paired with focused fixes/small sizes, merge probability reaches ~40-50%
Non-draft status is assumed positive baseline; draft status is strong negative signal reducing merge probability by ~20-30%
XS size class consistently outperforms other size classes for merge probability (~26-28%), particularly for first-time contributors
Author association labels (NONE, CONTRIBUTOR) provide minimal discriminative power; trusted/experienced labels far more predictive
